results.title: Coromby - every Monday night
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
The Coromby Brass Band is a group of farmers who come together every Monday night to practice in a draughty hall beside the wheat silos on a back road outside the small town of Murtoa. Formed in 1891, the band is the oldest continuously active brass band in Australia. Many members have been involved for decades - in some cases, their fathers and grandfathers played in the band before them. In this film, members of the band talk about what keeps them turning up at the hall “every Monday night”.

results.title: A Bulldog man
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
Lanz Bulldog tractors have been a big part of life in the Bolwell family since the 1930’s. Tim Bolwell has inherited his father’s collection of almost 30 Bulldog tractors, as well as an encyclopedic knowledge of the history and mechanics of these unusual machines. In this film, Tim explains the attraction of the Bulldog and its historical importance for many farmers in the Wimmera region.

results.title: Mugging: a case study in communication
results.creator_credit: Victor Lockwood and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Making Sense of Society”.
Looks at the press coverage of “mugging” to illustrate some points about the social nature of mass communications. Brings together and connects the two themes of communication and crime. Stuart Hall, of the University of Birmingham looks at and discusses these issues.

results.title: Unemployment
results.creator_credit: Graeme Turner, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Making Sense of Society”.
Presents two real-life cases of individuals who have actually experienced being unemployed. Dave Hunt of Sunderland has been out of work for 8 years. John Lockyer of Watford was unemployed for 4 months in 1971 but has been continuously in employment since then. Demonstrates the effect unemployment has had on their lives and their families.

results.title: Power in society: San Francisco bay area rapid transit winning public support
results.creator_credit: Graeme Turner, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Making Sense of Society”.
Looks at the setting up of a rapid transit system in San Francisco and the actions of the various county councils involved. Examines the roles of individuals within these organizations, their interactions and different levels of power and influence in participating in this scheme.

results.title: Hand painted strip slide magic lantern with chimney
results.brief_description:
Hand painted strip slide magic lantern projector with chimney, and one set of hand painted glass slides (in restored condition).
Strip slide is a single sheet of glass with hand painting directly on to glass. Slide has a wooden frame (stable condition)
1 x Box containing projector
1 x Package containing glass slide (VERY FRAGILE)

group_siblings.title: Child's toy tin magic lantern with candle projection
group_siblings.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.

results.title: Child's toy tin magic lantern with candle projection
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description:
Magic Lantern with removable chimney and internal wooden block.

The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit was donated by Edwin Schefferle - “When Edwin was about 10 years of age, he acquired a Magic Lantern Outfit from his Grandma. This fired his imagination; he would make images with ink on strips of cellophane and project these through the Magic Lantern by means of a candle onto an old sheet draped on the wall. The result was disappointing but encouraging. The one candle did not provide sufficient light especially during daylight. Little did he realise that he had opened a door on a world of projecting images on large screens. He had abandoned merry-go-rounds and wind mills but this was different. He never let go of his Magic Lantern; it could well have been dubbed his lighthouse showing him the way to go. What happened to his Magic Lantern? After his death in 2014 it was found among his belongings and was donated to the Australian Centre for Moving Image (ACMI) which superseded the State Film Centre, where Edwin spent most of his working life.” (text from book - ‘Life with a Purpose, Conversations with Edwin James Schefferle - Scheff’)
results.title_for_label: Child’s toy tin magic lantern with candle projection

results.title: Glass slide magic lantern
results.brief_description:
Glass slide projector as used by Department of Agriculture, Melbourne.
Lens can be compacted or extended, see attached images from ICS.
Modifications include addition of electricity and edision bulb.
1 Box containing 2 parts.
